text: pancakes are hands-down my favorite
thing to make on weekends when family
and friends come over for brunch I like
to make gingerbread pancakes it's so
simple start with three cups of
all-purpose flour to that we need
leavening three-quarters of a teaspoon
of baking soda and a quarter teaspoon
measure here okay a tablespoon of baking
powder a teaspoon of coarse salt goes in
and for the gingerbread spices two
teaspoons of ginger ground two teaspoons
of cinnamon ground and the thing that
really sets this apart is the ground
clove quarter teaspoon is all you need
it's very strong and nutmeg use freshly
grated nutmeg so buy the whole nutmeg
and use a little microplane zester and
you can measure this into a bowl first
but I'll just eyeball it
now we aerate these with a whisk you do
not have to sift anymore
you can simply aerate and combine the
ingredients with a whisk now for the wet
ingredients very straightforward make a
well in your dry ingredients you don't
have to whisk the wet ingredients
separately three cups of buttermilk
should be well shaken before you measure
it you can also make your own by adding
a tablespoon of lemon juice or white
vinegar to each cup of plain milk let it
sit for about five minutes and it'll
curdle and thicken and have that little
bit of Tang that you get from buttermilk
three large eggs if you have the
foresight have them at room temperature
it just makes things a bit easier and
molasses that also gives it that
gingerbread flavor what I like to do is
take a little bit of oil and just brush
it on the inside of the measuring cup
what that does is it helps it to slide
right out without you having to suffer
too much and we measure out 1/3 cup of
the molasses be sure you're using
regular unsalted molasses and not
blackstrap it has a much stronger flavor
and different texture that you're not
going to want in these pancakes and that
goes right into the bowl as well and see
how that slides right on out of there we
don't want to waste a drop okay and just
give this all a whisk until it's
combined don't over mix it otherwise
you're gonna have flat tough pancakes
this is just until it comes
together into a batter and once you have
the batter the very best thing to do is
to let it rest on the countertop for
about 15 or 20 minutes until you start
to see little bubbles forming in the
batter and that means that it's nice and
ready for the heat okay beautiful
consistency you can see it's nice and
thick and we'll just let this sit for a
few minutes and start cooking for the
cooking I have a handy countertop
electric griddle here but I also love to
use cast iron with the eggs it gives
beautiful color and crisp edges you
don't want a lot of oil on this kind of
nonstick surface so I like to just take
a paper towel and sort of brush it all
over and this is a quarter cup ice cream
scoop I like to use it because it's
clean and efficient and you get evenly
sized pancakes every time I think six is
all we're gonna get on here at once and
these are ready to flip when you start
to see bubbles once you see the bubbles
in the center you know it's just about
time all right here we go
and you have to just be brave and go for
it do not hesitate just flip you can see
that they have a nice golden color not
too dark and they smell amazing they
really do smell just like gingerbread
cookies I like to transfer these to a
baking sheet lined with a wire rack and
then I'll just pop them into a warm oven
maybe 200 225 degrees that way every
pancake is hot and crispy when it comes
to the table is there anything more
enticing than a stack of warm pancakes
on a weekend morning with butter and
maple syrup and these are scented with
those gingerbread spices and that sweet
molasses these look and smell totally
insane
I hope you enjoy these gingerbread
pancakes
you
you
